These stories often update the Western themes and motifs to address contemporary issues, while still incorporating the iconic elements that define the Western genre, such as landscapes, characters, and themes of morality and justice.
Image_Caption: Ben Foster and Chris Pine in Hell or High Water (2016)

Name: Western Epic
Description: The Western epic subgenre features grand storytelling, large-scale production, expansive landscapes, and often intricate narratives that span significant time periods. These stories capture the epic nature of historical events, characters, and themes associated with the American frontier.
Image_Caption: Henry Fonda and Charles Bronson in Once Upon a Time in the West (1968)

Name: Spaghetti Western
Description: The spaghetti Western subgenre, primarily produced by Italian filmmakers and filmed in Europe in the mid-20th century, features a distinctive style and unique approach to the traditional Western genre. They are often characterized by their gritty and stylized visuals, unconventional storytelling, and use of Italian filmmakers, actors, and locations.
Image_Caption: Clint Eastwood in The Good, the Bad and the Ugly (1966)

Name: Western
Description: The Western genre features stories set primarily in the 19th-century American Old West and often depict the rugged frontier life, exploring themes of individualism, justice, morality, and the clash between civilization and the untamed wilderness. The genre has its roots in the historical context of westward expansion and the challenges faced by pioneers, settlers, outlaws, and lawmen.
Image_Caption: John Wayne and Harry Carey Jr. in The Searchers (1956)

Name: Holiday
Description: The holiday genre features winter holidays, such as Christmas, Thanksgiving, Hanukkah, New Year's Eve, or other cultural and religious celebrations. These stories often capture the spirit, traditions, and emotions associated with these special times, making them ideal for seasonal viewing. The holiday genre can further branch into subgenres like holiday comedy, holiday romance, and holiday family.
Image_Caption: James Stewart, Donna Reed, Beulah Bondi, Carol Coombs, Karolyn Grimes, and Thomas Mitchell in It's a Wonderful Life (1946)

Name: Holiday Animation
Description: The holiday animation subgenre features animated stories that focus on winter holiday themes, traditions, and celebrations. These stories use animation techniques including hand-drawn animation, computer animation, and stop motion animation to bring festive stories to life, often targeting audiences of all ages.
Image_Caption: Boris Karloff in How the Grinch Stole Christmas! (1966)

Name: Holiday Comedy
Description: The holiday comedy subgenre combines elements of humor with the festive spirit of the holiday season. These movies are typically light-hearted, often featuring comedic situations, humorously exaggerated characters, and amusing plots set against the backdrop of a holiday celebration, such as Christmas, Thanksgiving, Hanukkah, New Year's Eve, or other cultural and religious celebrations.
Image_Caption: Chevy Chase in National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation (1989)

Name: Holiday Family
Description: The holiday family subgenre features themes related to the holidays, with a focus on family dynamics, cultural traditions, and the magic of the holiday season. These films are often heartwarming, light-hearted, and family-friendly as they capture the spirit of various winter holidays, such as Christmas, Thanksgiving, Hanukkah, New Year's Eve, or other cultural and religious celebrations.
Image_Caption: Phylicia Rashad in Jingle Jangle: A Christmas Journey (2020)

Name: Holiday Romance
Description: The holiday romance subgenre combines elements of romantic storytelling with the festive atmosphere of the holidays. These movies often center around characters who experience love and romance during winter holiday seasons, such as Christmas, Thanksgiving, Hanukkah, New Year's Eve, or other cultural and religious celebrations. The plots typically involve themes of love, relationships, and the magic of the holiday season.
Image_Caption: Philemon Chambers and Michael Urie in Single All the Way (2021)

Name: Gun Fu
Description: The gun fu subgenre features highly choreographed gun battles that incorporate stylized martial arts, acrobatics, and fluid gun handling. These battles often involve close-quarters combat, dynamic camera work, and rapid editing to create a sense of frenetic energy and excitement.
Image_Caption: Keanu Reeves in The Matrix (1999)

Name: Kung Fu
Description: The kung fu subgenre features the practice and mastery of Chinese martial arts. In Chinese, "kung fu" refers to any skill acquired through practice. Born as a backlash against the supernatural tropes of wuxia, the kung fu subgenre depicts realistic, unarmed fight choreography, highlighting the skill, speed, and agility of the martial artists involved, as well as the discipline, patience and strength required to become a master.
Image_Caption: Donnie Yen in Ip Man 3 (2015)

Name: Samurai
Description: The samurai subgenre, also known as chanbara, features the samurai warrior class and their way of life. These stories explore themes found within bushido, or "the way of the warrior," a moral code that guides samurai attitudes, behavior and lifestyle. Often set in feudal Japan during the Edo period (1603�1868), samurai stories depict the tension between tradition and modernization, the struggle for power and justice, and the decline of a traditional way of life.
Image_Caption: Toshirô Mifune, Minoru Chiaki, Daisuke Katô, Isao Kimura, Seiji Miyaguchi, and Takashi Shimura in Seven Samurai (1954)

Name: Wuxia
Description: The wuxia subgenre features the adventures of chivalrous heroes in ancient China who possess extraordinary martial arts skills, sometimes bordering on the supernatural. Wuxia heroes strive to redress wrongs, fight for righteousness, remove oppressors, and bring retribution for past misdeeds. These stories depict highly stylized action sequences, characterized by gravity-defying stunts, intricate choreography, and the use of various weapons.
Image_Caption: Maggie Cheung in Hero (2002)

Name: Isekai
Description: Isekai is a subgenre of Japanese animation that features characters who are transported from their ordinary lives into parallel worlds or alternate dimensions. These anime follow the characters' adventures as they navigate their new surroundings, encounter fantastical creatures, and embark on missions or quests.
Image_Caption: Jun Fukushima in Konosuba: God's Blessing on This Wonderful World! (2016)

Name: Iyashikei
Description: Iyashikei is a subgenre of Japanese animation that aims to provide a sense of healing, relaxation, and comfort. These anime are characterized by their gentle pacing, serene atmospheres, and focus on everyday life and nature.
Image_Caption: Natsume's Book of Friends (2008)

Name: Josei
Description: Josei is a subgenre of Japanese animation that is intended for adult women. These anime typically focus on realistic portrayals of relationships, emotions, and everyday life.
Image_Caption: Kids on the Slope (2012)

Name: Mecha
Description: Mecha is a subgenre of Japanese animation that features giant robots or mechs that are controlled by pilots or artificial intelligence.
Image_Caption: Mobile Suit Gundam: The Witch from Mercury (2022)

Name: Seinen
Description: Seinen is a subgenre of Japanese animation that is intended for adult men. These anime often explore mature themes and complex narratives, such as psychological drama, crime, and existentialism.
Image_Caption: Perfect Blue (1997)

Name: Shōnen
Description: Shōnen is a subgenre of Japanese animation that is intended for young male audiences. These anime typically feature heroic, action-packed stories with themes of friendship, perseverance, and self-improvement.
Image_Caption: One Piece (1999)

Name: Shōjo
Description: Shōjo is a subgenre of Japanese animation that is intended for young female audiences. These anime typically focus on themes of romance, relationships, and personal growth, often featuring female characters navigating the complexities of love, friendship, and self-discovery.
Image_Caption: Nobunaga Shimazaki and Manaka Iwami in Let's Start the Watermelon Splitting Contest! (2020)

Name: Slice of Life
Description: Slice of life is a subgenre of Japanese animation that portrays everyday life, often without a central plot or overarching narrative. Instead, slice of life anime captures the ordinary experiences, interactions, and emotions of its characters, offering a glimpse into their daily routines and struggles.
Image_Caption: Barakamon (2014)

Name: Korean Drama
Description: The Korean Drama (K-Drama) subgenre features TV series that highlight South Korea's entertainment industry through its romantic and thrilling dramatic storytelling.
Image_Caption: Son Ye-jin and Hyun Bin in Crash Landing on You (2019)

Name: Telenovela
Description: The Telenovela subgenre features TV series that highlight the larger than life passion, drama and romance of Latin American soap operas. These stories often contain unsuspecting plot twists, love triangles and even murder.
Image_Caption: Kate del Castillo in La Reina del Sur (2011)

Name: News
Description: The news genre delivers timely and factual information about current events, developments, and issues of public interest. The primary purpose of news content is to inform the audience about what is happening in the world around them, providing them with essential facts, analysis, and context.
Image_Caption: Tom Brokaw

Name: Short
Description: The short form refers to creative works characterized by their brevity and concise storytelling. Unlike full-length feature films, short films have a running time of less than 45 minutes, while TV shorts have a running time of less than 22 minutes.
Image_Caption: Benedict Cumberbatch in The Wonderful Story of Henry Sugar (2023)
